0.body: Goal: Create a file and initialise pygame.
0.title: Task 1: Set Up

1.body: In VS Code, click on File and then New File... File New File You should see something like this pop up after you cilck 'New File' Pop Up Enter the name of your file (e.g. 'my_game.py') my_game.py ``` NOTE: It’s super important to include .py at the end of the file name so VS Code knows it's Python code! Press 'ENTER' and something looks like this should pop up my_game.py Press 'Desktop' and then 'Create File' to save your file to the Desktop my_game.py my_game.py AND NOW YOU HAVE CREATED YOUR PYTHON FILE!!! YOU CAN START CODING my_game.py
1.breadcrumbs: SET UP » Make a Python File » Task 1.1: Make Python File
1.title: Task 1.1: Make Python File

10.body: No crashing! Your window should stay open until you click the X! You should see something like this: black game window
10.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Loop » Checkpoints
10.title: Checkpoints

11.body: First save the image path as a variable : e.g.background_image = "images/background/wooden_floor.jpeg" Then load it using pygame.image.load(background_image) make sure the background fits the window Use pygame.transform.scale(...) draw the background onto the screen use screen.blit(...)
11.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Add Background Image » Task 2.3: Add Background Image
11.title: Task 2.3: Add Background Image

12.body: A background_image variable (path to the image) A background variable (the scaled loaded image) A screen.blit(variable, coordinate) line inside your while running: loop A background showing up instead of a black screen!
12.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Add Background Image » Checkpoints
12.title: Checkpoints

13.body: Change the text that appears at the very top of your game window use a Pygame function pygame.display.set_caption(). load an image using pygame.image.load(...) use Pygame function pygame.display.set_icon() to set the image. The path to your icon should be something like this: "images/game_icon.png"
13.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Add Icon and Game Title » Task 2.4: Add a Game Title and App Icon
13.title: Task 2.4: Add a Game Title and App Icon

15.body: Goal: Make a player that can move and be seen on the screen.
15.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Task 3: Making a player
15.title: Task 3: Making a player

16.body: We'll create a Player class to store: The player’s position, size and image (sprite)
16.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Create a Player Class » Task 3.1: Create a Player Class
16.title: Task 3.1: Create a Player Class

17.body: - Use the `class` keyword. - The class name should start with a **capital letter**. Inside your Player class, create an __init__() method.
17.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Create a Player Class » Hint:
17.title: Hint:

18.body: - Use the `def` keyword to define the method. - The `__init__()` method should only have `self` as its input. Inside your __init__() method, create the following properties: position_x -> set it to 0 for now position_y ->set it to 0 for now size -> (width, height) image -> file name Load and Scale the Player’s Sprite inside your __init__() method:
18.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Create a Player Class » Hints:
18.title: Hints:

19.body: - Use `pygame.image.load(...)` to load the player image file. - Use `pygame.transform.scale(...)` to resize the player’s image to the correct size.
19.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Create a Player Class » Hints:
19.title: Hints:

2.body: Now that you have created your Python file, it's time to start setting it up for Pygame! At the very top of your Python file, you need to import the Pygame library. Initialising Pygame You should now see something like this: Pygame Init
2.breadcrumbs: SET UP » Import Pygame » Task 1.2: Import Pygame
2.title: Task 1.2: Import Pygame

22.body: Use the class name with brackets () to create a new object. Save it into a variable called player. After you create the player instance, print out the player’s important properties to check they were created correctly.

- Print the player's `position_y`
- Print the player's `size`

3.body: Goal: Create a visible game screen with a background, title, icon and a game loop.
3.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 2: Creating a game screen
3.title: Task 2: Creating a game screen

30.body: - Use the `def` keyword. - Remember to give it just one parameter: `self`. Use pygame.key.get_pressed() to check which keys are currently being held down and save the result into a variable Check if the player is pressing: | Key | Action | |:----|:-------| | W key | Move up | | A key | Move left | | S key | Move down | | D key | Move right |
30.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Implement Player Move method » Hints:
30.title: Hints:

31.body: If the W key is pressed, decrease the y position. If the S key is pressed, increase the y position. If the A key is pressed, decrease the x position. If the D key is pressed, increase the x position. change the player's image depending on the direction they are moving
31.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Implement Player Move method » Hints:
31.title: Hints:

32.body: - When moving **up**, change the image to "poco_up.png" - When moving **down**, change the image to "poco_down.png" - When moving **left**, change the image to "poco_left.png" - When moving **right**, change the image to "poco_right.png"
32.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Implement Player Move method » Hints:
32.title: Hints:

33.body: A move() method inside your Player class The method checks which keys are pressed [ ]The method updates the player’s position_x and position_y The player image changes when moving!
33.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Implement Player Move method » Checkpoints
33.title: Checkpoints

34.body: Inside your while running: game loop, at the very start of the loop (before drawing the player or foods), draw the background again over the whole screen.

37.body: Goal: Add multiple entities that are related to each other. In this example we have added food, but you are free to add what you wish, as long as it is appropriate.
37.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Task 4: Adding other entities
37.title: Task 4: Adding other entities

38.body: Start by creating a new class called Food.
38.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create a Food Class » Task 4.1: Create a Food Class
38.title: Task 4.1: Create a Food Class

39.body: class Food: Inside your Food class, create a special function called __init__.

39.title: Example:

4.body: Before we make our game we need to set up the screen to display it! Make a screen that is 800 pixels wide and 600 pixels tall For example: To make a screen that is 100 pixels wide and 200 pixels tall you could use this code WIDTH = 100 HEIGHT = 200 Create a window** of that size using the Pygame function pygame.display.set_mode()
4.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Screen » Task 2.1: Create Game Screen
4.title: Task 2.1: Create Game Screen

40.body: Use the def keyword to define the method. The __init__ method should accept 4 inputs : name image position_x position_y Save each of these inputs into the object using self. Inside your __init__() method, set a default size for your food. Still inside the __init__() method, load the image file using Pygame's image load function. Scale the loaded image to the correct size using Pygame's transform scale function. Save the final scaled image into the object (e.g., self.sprite).
40.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create a Food Class » Hints:
40.title: Hints:

41.body: A Food class (or a class of things you want to have) An __init__() method that: Saves the name, image, and position Sets a default size Loads and scales the sprite A ready-to-use object for your game!
41.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create a Food Class » Checkpoints
41.title: Checkpoints

42.body: Create a dictionary called foods, this dictionary will hold all the food items you want to appear in your game.
42.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create a Food Dictionary » Task 4.2: Create a Food Dictionary
42.title: Task 4.2: Create a Food Dictionary

43.body: Use curly braces {} to create a dictionary. Save it in your main code before your game loop starts. Inside your dictionary, add entries for each food you want Each key should be the name of the food (like "banana", "grapes", etc.). Each value should be a list that contains: The path to the image file The x position The y position
43.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create a Food Dictionary » Hint:
43.title: Hint:

44.title: Hint for structure:

45.body: Create a new empty list called active_foods, this list will store all the Food objects you create. Write a for loop that goes through every item in your foods dictionary. In each loop, you will create a new Food object.
45.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Initialise Active Foods List » Task 4.3: Initialise Active Foods List
45.title: Task 4.3: Initialise Active Foods List

46.body: Use .items() to loop through both the key and value . The key will be the name of the food. The value will be a list containing: [image path, x position, y position] Create a New Food Object for Each Item

53.body: Now that each Food knows how to draw itself, it's time to actually draw all the food onto your game window during the game! You will loop through all active foods inside your while running: game loop.
53.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Draw Active Foods in Game Loop » Task 4.5: Draw Active Foods in Game Loop
53.title: Task 4.5: Draw Active Foods in Game Loop

54.body: Create a for loop inside your while running: loop which loop over the active_foods list. In each loop call the draw() method on the food to draw it on screen.
54.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Draw Active Foods in Game Loop » Step 1: Loop Over active_foods
54.title: Step 1: Loop Over active_foods

55.body: Inside the for loop: use player's method to check for interaction with the food. call the food’s .draw() method.

57.body: Goal: Detect whether the player is colliding with any of the food.
57.title: Task 5: Collision

58.body: Create an extra property in the player and food class. Use the .get_rect().move() function to create a rectangle that moves with the class' sprite. Create a method called update(self) in the player class. Copy the property you just wrote into this method. Call the player update method in the main game loop, just underneath player.draw()
58.breadcrumbs: COLLISION » Creating Hitboxes » Task 5.1: Create a hitbox for both the players and the foods
58.title: Task 5.1: Create a hitbox for both the players and the foods

59.body:
# sprite.get_rect() creates a rectangle the size of the image
# .move() moves whatever it's attached to to an x and y coordinate
self.hitbox = self.sprite.get_rect().move(self.position_x, self.position_y)
59.title: Hint

6.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Screen » You must complete Task 1.2 first BEFORE YOU CAN SEE A SCREEN WHEN YOU RUN YOUR PYGAME!
6.title: You must complete Task 1.2 first BEFORE YOU CAN SEE A SCREEN WHEN YOU RUN YOUR PYGAME!

60.body: Create a property called interact_foods(self, food) in the food class Use the colliderect to check whether the rectangular hitboxes are colliding If they are colliding, remove food from the active_foods list
60.breadcrumbs: COLLISION » Detecting Collision » Task 5.2: Check whether two hitboxes are colliding
60.title: Task 5.2: Check whether two hitboxes are colliding

61.body:
# Collision is True is the hitboxes are colliding and False if not
collision = self.hitbox.colliderect(food.hitbox)
61.title: Hint

62.body: Goal: Add a score, a win condition. Finishing this task finishes the basic features of your game.
62.breadcrumbs: FINISHING THE BASE GAME » Task 6: Finishing the game.
62.title: Task 6: Finishing the game.

63.body: Create a player property called score Everytime that a user picks up a new item, update this variable.
63.breadcrumbs: FINISHING THE BASE GAME » Implement a Score » Task 6.1: Create a player score
63.title: Task 6.1: Create a player score

64.body: If the the player picks up all the items or the score is equal to the number of items, then end the game and quit.
64.breadcrumbs: FINISHING THE BASE GAME » Implement a Win Condition » Task 6.2: Game Win condition
64.title: Task 6.2: Game Win condition

65.body: Perhaps setting running = False will do something.
65.breadcrumbs: FINISHING THE BASE GAME » Implement a Win Condition » Hints
65.title: Hints

66.body: Render the score on the screen. We can use font.render(). blit the text onto the screen. Experiment with where you would put the score!
66.breadcrumbs: FINISHING THE BASE GAME » Display the Score » Task 6.3: Show the score on the screen
66.title: Task 6.3: Show the score on the screen

67.body:
# Setting fonts in pygame
colour = (256, 256, 256) # (R,G,B) # Creating text - concatenate "Score: " and the score variable
# https://www.pygame.org/docs/ref/font.html#pygame.font.Font.render
font.render("Score: " + score, True, colour) # Drawing on the screen
screen.blit(image, (x_position, y_position))
67.breadcrumbs: FINISHING THE BASE GAME » Display the Score » Hints
67.title: Hints

7.body: Two variables for width and height A screen object created using Pygame and your variables
7.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Screen » Checkpoint
7.title: Checkpoint

8.body: Use a variable called running and set it to True at the start Then you need a while loop which keep looping while the game is running . Inside your while running: loop, you need to check what the player is doing .
8.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Loop » Task 2.2: Create Game Loop
8.title: Task 2.2: Create Game Loop

9.body: Use for event in pygame.event.get(): Go through all the events (like mouse clicks, window close, etc.) If the player close the game (event.type == pygame.QUIT`), you need to stop the loop ! At the end of your while loop, refresh the screen with pygame.display.update()
9.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Loop » Hint:
9.title: Hint:
